metadata.title: Hemorrhagic Shock - Pelvic Trauma
learning_objectives: Recognize hemorrhagic shock (tachycardia, hypotension, altered mental status)
Identify pelvic fracture as source of occult bleeding
Prioritize rapid transport over scene interventions

changelog.v3.0_enhanced: New scenario with Blueprint Structure Enhancement v2: matching config, clinical anchors, consequence templates, ECG standardization. Deterioration timing 5/9/13 min. 20-minute duration.

dispatch_info.additional_info: Woman hit by car, conscious but confused, lying on ground

scene_description.location: Urban street at crosswalk, patient lying on asphalt, vehicle stopped nearby
scene_description.safety: Scene secured by police, traffic diverted, glass debris on road
scene_description.bystanders: Driver distraught but uninjured, several witnesses, police on scene

patient_profile.name: Marta
patient_profile.personality: Initially confused and agitated, complaining of pain, becomes quieter as shock progresses

initial.student_sees: You arrive to find a young woman lying supine on the asphalt next to a crosswalk. She's pale and sweaty despite the cool weather. Her eyes are open but she looks confused and frightened. 'It hurts... my hips... please help me,' she says weakly. You can see an abrasion on her left hip through torn clothing. Her legs are slightly externally rotated. A witness tells you: 'The car was turning right and hit her - maybe 30 km/h. She flew about 2 meters and landed on her back. She's been awake the whole time but getting more confused.' You notice her clothing is wet in the groin area - could be urine or blood. The driver is standing nearby, shaking: 'I didn't see her, I swear I didn't see her.'
initial.appearance: Young female, pale, diaphoretic, confused, externally rotated legs, abrasion left hip, lying supine
initial.clinical_note: HEMORRHAGIC SHOCK Class II-III. Mechanism: pedestrian struck by vehicle with lateral impact to pelvis. Tachycardia (128), hypotension (92/68), delayed capillary refill (4 sec), and confusion indicate significant blood loss. Pelvic fracture can hide 2-4 liters of blood in retroperitoneal space. DO NOT repeatedly test pelvic stability. Apply pelvic binder and transport rapidly.

improving.student_sees: After your interventions, the patient appears slightly more stable. Her color is still pale but she's more alert. 'What happened? Was I hit by a car?' The pelvic binder is in place. She's still complaining of hip pain but is answering questions more appropriately. Her pulse feels slightly stronger. 'Am I going to be okay?' she asks.
improving.appearance: Pelvic binder in place, more alert, still pale but stable, appropriate responses
improving.clinical_note: Pelvic binder applied - helps tamponade bleeding. Shock NOT reversed but stabilized. Key now is RAPID TRANSPORT to trauma center with blood products. Do not delay for IV if it delays transport. Permissive hypotension target: SBP 80-90.

deteriorating.student_sees: The patient's condition is worsening. She's become much quieter and is no longer responding to questions - just moaning weakly. Her skin is now gray and mottled, especially on her knees and elbows. Her pulse is very rapid and thready - hard to feel at the wrist. 'Stay with me, Marta!' you say. Her eyes flutter but she doesn't respond coherently. You notice the wet area in her groin has spread.
deteriorating.appearance: Unresponsive to verbal, mottled skin, thready pulse, increasing blood at pelvis
deteriorating.clinical_note: Class III-IV hemorrhagic shock. Decompensating - blood loss exceeds compensation. This patient is bleeding to death internally. Aggressive transport needed NOW. Blood products are the treatment, not crystalloid.

critical.student_sees: CRITICAL: The patient is now unresponsive. Her skin is gray, cold, and mottled. You cannot palpate a radial pulse - only a weak, rapid carotid pulse. Her breathing is shallow and rapid. She's not responding to anything. This is Class IV hemorrhagic shock - she's dying from blood loss.
critical.appearance: Unresponsive, gray mottled skin, no radial pulse, agonal state
critical.clinical_note: Class IV hemorrhagic shock - >40% blood volume lost. Without immediate blood transfusion and surgical intervention, death is imminent. Crystalloid cannot save this patient - she needs blood products and surgery.

circulation.initial: HR 128, BP 92/68, pulse weak and rapid, CRT 4 seconds, pale, diaphoretic, cool peripheries EXCEPT warm near pelvis (internal bleeding)
circulation.deteriorating: HR 140, BP 72/50, thready pulse, mottled skin
circulation.critical: HR 150, BP unrecordable, no radial pulse, severe mottling

exposure.left_hip: Large abrasion and developing hematoma over iliac crest
exposure.pelvis: Externally rotated legs suggest pelvic disruption. DO NOT repeatedly test pelvic stability - one gentle assessment only, if positive STOP and apply binder.
exposure.perineum: Blood visible at vaginal area - concerning for open pelvic fracture
exposure.other: No obvious long bone fractures, abdomen soft but distended

sample_history.symptoms: Severe hip/pelvic pain, dizziness, thirst, confusion
sample_history.events: Witness: 'She was crossing with green light. Car turning right hit her at maybe 30 km/h. Direct impact to her left side. Thrown about 2 meters, landed on back. No head strike seen. Conscious whole time but getting more confused.'

pelvic_assessment.inspection: External rotation of legs, abrasion over left iliac crest, blood at perineum
pelvic_assessment.palpation: ONE gentle assessment only - if instability felt, STOP. Do NOT rock pelvis repeatedly.
pelvic_assessment.finding: Unstable pelvis with crepitus on gentle lateral compression

interpretation.mechanism: Compensatory response to blood loss and shock

ecg_findings.teaching_point: ECG is NOT a priority in hemorrhagic shock. Tachycardia is compensatory - do NOT treat it. Low voltage reflects hypovolemia. Focus on hemorrhage control (pelvic binder) and rapid transport. ECG may be useful to rule out cardiac contusion if blunt chest trauma.

pelvic_binder.device: Commercial pelvic binder or improvised sheet wrap
pelvic_binder.application: At level of greater trochanters, snug but not crushing
pelvic_binder.mechanism: Reduces pelvic volume, allows tamponade of venous bleeding

scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: Pelvic volume reduced, bleeding tamponaded, prevents further blood loss but does NOT replace lost blood

iv_access.approach: Two large bore (16-18G) if possible without delaying transport

scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: IV access is important but do NOT delay transport to establish it. Can be done en route.
Crystalloid doesn't carry oxygen or clot. Over-resuscitation dilutes clotting factors and increases bleeding. Target SBP 80-90 until surgical control.

5min.description: Shock progressing, becoming more confused, skin mottling appearing, pulse harder to feel

9min.description: Decompensating, responds only to pain, severe mottling, no radial pulse palpable

13min.description: Class IV shock, near-arrest, unresponsive, agonal breathing, imminent cardiac arrest

critical_harm.name: excessive_fluids
critical_harm.description: More than 2L crystalloid without blood products
critical_harm.why_dangerous: Dilutes clotting factors, causes hypothermia, increases bleeding

if_given.clinical_effect: Initially BP improves, then patient bleeds more as clots are disrupted

critical_harm.teaching_point: Crystalloid doesn't carry oxygen or clot. You can't 'fill the tank' faster than it leaks. The treatment is surgical control and blood products, not saline.

worsens.name: repeated_pelvic_examination
worsens.why_wrong: Disrupts any clot formation, increases bleeding
worsens.teaching_point: Assess pelvis ONCE. If unstable, apply binder and STOP examining. Each manipulation disrupts clots and increases bleeding.

neutral.name: tranexamic_acid
neutral.indication: Hemorrhagic shock within 3 hours of injury

if_given.clinical_effect: Antifibrinolytic - helps maintain clots. Appropriate if available and within time window.

neutral.teaching_point: TXA reduces mortality in hemorrhagic shock if given within 3 hours. Dose: 1g IV over 10 minutes. Follow local protocols.

critical_failures.description: Pelvic binder never applied to unstable pelvic fracture
critical_failures.patient_outcome: Without pelvic binding, the pelvis remains an unstable, expanding cavity. Venous bleeding continues uncontrolled. Patient exsanguinates from preventable hemorrhage. Can lose 4+ liters into unbound pelvis.
critical_failures.aar_teaching_point: Pelvic binder is THE life-saving intervention for unstable pelvic fractures. It reduces pelvic volume, tamponades venous bleeding, and allows clot formation. Without it, the pelvis is a 4-liter bucket that keeps expanding. This patient will bleed to death without mechanical hemorrhage control. Application must be immediate - it's as critical as a tourniquet for extremity bleeding.

critical_failures.description: Excessive fluid resuscitation (>2L crystalloid) before hemorrhage control
critical_failures.patient_outcome: Over-resuscitation without hemorrhage control causes dilutional coagulopathy (clotting factors diluted), hypothermia (cold fluids), disrupts forming clots with hydrostatic pressure, and accelerates bleeding. Patient enters 'lethal triad' of hypothermia, coagulopathy, acidosis. Death from medical over-treatment.
critical_failures.aar_teaching_point: You cannot fill the tank faster than it leaks. Crystalloid doesn't carry oxygen and doesn't clot - it just dilutes the blood that's left. Over-resuscitation before hemorrhage control makes bleeding worse through three mechanisms: dilutes clotting factors, causes hypothermia, and increases hydrostatic pressure that disrupts clots. Target permissive hypotension (SBP 80-90) with small boluses. Definitive treatment is surgical hemostasis and blood products, not saline.

critical_failures.description: Repeated pelvic examinations (>1 assessment of stability)
critical_failures.patient_outcome: Each pelvic manipulation disrupts fragile clot formation in fracture sites. Every 'spring' or stability check re-opens bleeding. Iatrogenic acceleration of hemorrhage from repeated examination.
critical_failures.aar_teaching_point: Assess pelvic stability ONCE. If unstable: apply binder and NEVER examine again. Each manipulation tears newly formed clots and restarts venous bleeding. This is iatrogenic harm - you're actively worsening the injury. The saying is: 'Check the pelvis once. After that, you're just stirring up the bleeding.'

critical_failures.description: Prolonged scene time (>10 minutes) for non-essential interventions
critical_failures.patient_outcome: Every minute on scene is a minute patient continues to exsanguinate. Definitive treatment (surgery, blood products) only available in hospital. Delayed transport = preventable death from bleeding.
critical_failures.aar_teaching_point: Hemorrhagic shock requires load-and-go mentality. You cannot stop pelvic bleeding prehospitally - only slow it with binder. Definitive treatment is surgical hemorrhage control and blood product resuscitation, neither available on scene. Scene time should be <10 minutes: assess, binder, scoop and run. 'Staying and playing' kills hemorrhaging patients. Every minute on scene is a minute closer to death.

critical_failures.patient_outcome: Allergic reaction on top of hemorrhagic shock emergency
critical_failures.aar_teaching_point: Always verify allergies before medication administration.

initial.description: Hemorrhagic shock presentation - tachycardic (118), hypotensive (88/60), altered mental status, unstable pelvic fracture palpable, pale and diaphoretic. Compensated shock transitioning to decompensated.

early_deteriorating.description: Decompensation beginning - increasing tachycardia, blood pressure dropping further, confusion worsening, skin increasingly mottled

deteriorating.description: Severe decompensation - marked tachycardia, severe hypotension (SBP <70), significantly altered consciousness, gray and mottled, oliguric

critical.description: Pre-arrest hemorrhagic shock - profound hypotension, barely conscious or unconscious, imminent cardiac arrest from exsanguination

improving.timing: After hemorrhage control and judicious resuscitation
improving.description: Stabilized with mechanical hemorrhage control - pelvic binder applied, blood pressure maintained at permissive hypotension (80-90), mental status improving, bleeding slowed

stable.description: Temporarily stabilized for transport - binder in place, permissive hypotension maintained, ready for rapid transport to trauma surgery

critical_actions_checklist.criteria: Identifies tachycardia + hypotension + altered mental status = shock

exemplary.outcome_description: Hemorrhagic shock recognized immediately from vital signs triad
exemplary.feedback_template: Excellent recognition - you immediately identified hemorrhagic shock based on the classic triad: tachycardia (HR 118), hypotension (BP 88/60), and altered mental status. You understood this represents decompensated shock requiring immediate hemorrhage control and rapid transport. This rapid diagnosis enabled life-saving interventions.

competent.feedback_template: Good recognition of hemorrhagic shock. You identified the indicators and proceeded with appropriate hemorrhage control.

developing.outcome_description: Shock recognition delayed, patient critically decompensated
developing.feedback_template: Recognition of hemorrhagic shock was delayed. By the time you identified it, the patient was in {patient_state_at_action} state with profound hypotension - this is pre-arrest exsanguination. The triad of tachycardia, hypotension, and altered mental status with trauma mechanism should immediately trigger 'hemorrhagic shock' diagnosis. What was your assessment reasoning?

criteria: Didn't identify need for hemorrhage control
novice.outcome_description: Failed to recognize life-threatening hemorrhagic shock
novice.feedback_template: Hemorrhagic shock was not recognized. This patient had the classic presentation: traumatic mechanism, tachycardia (118), hypotension (88/60), altered mental status, pale and diaphoretic. This is decompensated hemorrhagic shock - actively dying from blood loss. Without recognition, appropriate hemorrhage control cannot be initiated.

critical_actions_checklist.criteria: ONE gentle pelvic assessment, identifies instability

exemplary.outcome_description: Pelvic instability identified with single, gentle assessment
exemplary.feedback_template: Excellent technique - you performed ONE gentle pelvic assessment and immediately identified the instability. You correctly understood that repeated examinations would disrupt clots and worsen bleeding. This is optimal trauma assessment - one check, then immediate binder application.

competent.feedback_template: Good pelvic assessment. You identified the instability and avoided repeated examinations.

developing.feedback_template: The pelvis was examined multiple times. Each examination disrupts fragile clot formation and increases bleeding. This is iatrogenic harm - you're making the injury worse by repeatedly 'springing' the pelvis. Assess stability ONCE, then apply binder and NEVER examine again.

novice.outcome_description: Critical injury missed or worsened by repeated examination
novice.feedback_template: Pelvic assessment was inadequate or harmful. With hemorrhagic shock and trauma mechanism, pelvic fracture must be immediately considered. Assess ONCE to identify instability, then stop examining.

critical_actions_checklist.criteria: Applied at level of greater trochanters

exemplary.outcome_description: Pelvic binder applied immediately, hemorrhage controlled, shock reversed
exemplary.feedback_template: Excellent hemorrhage control - pelvic binder applied immediately after identifying instability. You prevented exsanguination by mechanically reducing pelvic volume and allowing venous tamponade. The patient's blood pressure stabilized, mental status improved, and bleeding slowed. This is life-saving intervention performed at optimal timing. You correctly positioned it at the greater trochanters for maximum mechanical advantage.

competent.outcome_description: Binder applied before critical decompensation, patient stabilized
competent.feedback_template: Effective hemorrhage control with pelvic binder. Patient stabilized with mechanical reduction of pelvic volume. Some deterioration occurred but you intervened before irreversible shock.

developing.outcome_description: Binder application delayed, patient reached critical shock before control
developing.feedback_template: Pelvic binder was delayed until patient reached {patient_state_at_action} state with severe decompensation. During that time, uncontrolled pelvic bleeding continued - the pelvis can hold 4+ liters of blood without mechanical control. While treatment eventually worked, the delay allowed preventable hemorrhage and near-exsanguination. In unstable pelvic fractures, the binder is as urgent as a tourniquet on a spurting extremity wound. What delayed this critical intervention?

novice.outcome_description: Critical hemorrhage control omitted - patient died or nearly died
novice.feedback_template: This is addressed as a Safety Gate issue - pelvic binder is THE life-saving intervention for unstable pelvic fractures. Without it, this patient bleeds to death from uncontrolled venous hemorrhage.

critical_actions_checklist.criteria: Large bore IV, ideally two lines, but NOT delaying transport
Cover patient, warm fluids if available
Load and go mentality - trauma center with blood products

common_errors.teaching_point: Pelvic binder reduces pelvic volume and allows tamponade of venous bleeding
common_errors.clinical_anchor: The pelvis is a bucket that can hold 4 liters of blood. The binder makes the bucket smaller.

common_errors.teaching_point: Each examination disrupts clots and increases bleeding
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Check the pelvis ONCE. After that, you're just stirring up the bleeding.

common_errors.teaching_point: Crystalloid doesn't clot or carry oxygen - over-resuscitation worsens coagulopathy
common_errors.clinical_anchor: You can't fill the tank faster than it leaks. Saline doesn't clot and doesn't carry oxygen.

common_errors.teaching_point: Definitive treatment is surgery and blood products - not available prehospital
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Every minute on scene is a minute she's bleeding. Surgery stops bleeding, not bandages.

common_errors.teaching_point: Permissive hypotension (SBP 80-90) reduces bleeding until surgical control
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Normal BP in hemorrhage means more bleeding. Target 80-90 until the surgeon has control.
Fast heart, low pressure, foggy brain—she's lost at least 30% of her blood.

consequence_templates.template: Pelvic binder was NEVER applied. {patient_name} had an unstable pelvic fracture - a injury that can bleed 2-4 liters into the retroperitoneum. Without a binder to reduce pelvic volume and tamponade bleeding, she continued to hemorrhage throughout your care.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: Pelvic binders reduce mortality in pelvic fractures by enabling tamponade of venous bleeding. Without it, the pelvis acts as an expanding reservoir for blood.

consequence_templates.template: Pelvic binder applied at {actual_time} minutes (target: {target_time} minutes). During those {delay_minutes} minutes, {patient_name}'s pelvis remained unsupported and bleeding continued unchecked. Pelvic fracture bleeding is FAST - each minute of delay represents significant additional blood loss.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: Pelvic fracture bleeding can exceed 500ml per minute in severe cases. Early binder application is critical.

consequence_templates.template: Transport was delayed until {actual_time} minutes. The only treatment that can save {patient_name} is blood products and surgery - neither available on scene. Every minute on scene was a minute of continued bleeding.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: Hemorrhagic shock requires blood product resuscitation and surgical hemostasis. Scene time directly correlates with mortality.

critical_decision_points.description: Identifying hemorrhagic shock class and severity

scoring.optimal: Immediately recognized Class II-III shock from vitals (tachycardia, hypotension, delayed CRT, confusion). Verbalized concern for significant blood loss.
scoring.acceptable: Recognized patient in shock, initiated appropriate treatment.
scoring.dangerous: Failed to recognize shock, treated as minor injury.

critical_decision_points.clinical_anchor: Fast heart, low pressure, slow cap refill, foggy brain—that's 30% blood volume gone.
critical_decision_points.aar_teaching_point: Hemorrhagic shock classes: Class I (<15%) - normal vitals; Class II (15-30%) - tachycardia, narrowed pulse pressure; Class III (30-40%) - hypotension, confusion, oliguria; Class IV (>40%) - near-death. This patient: Class II-III transitioning.

critical_decision_points.description: Appropriate pelvic fracture assessment and management

scoring.optimal: Single gentle pelvic assessment, immediately recognized instability, applied binder without repeated examinations.
scoring.suboptimal: Multiple pelvic examinations before applying binder.
scoring.dangerous: No binder applied, or excessive pelvic manipulation.

critical_decision_points.clinical_anchor: One exam, one chance. After that, you're just making her bleed more.
critical_decision_points.aar_teaching_point: Pelvic fractures can hide massive hemorrhage. Assess ONCE - if unstable, apply binder immediately at level of greater trochanters. DO NOT repeatedly rock or compress pelvis - each manipulation disrupts clots.

critical_decision_points.description: Appropriate fluid resuscitation and permissive hypotension

scoring.optimal: Small boluses (250ml) targeting SBP 80-90, verbalized permissive hypotension concept, prioritized transport over IV fluids.
scoring.suboptimal: Attempted to normalize blood pressure with large fluid volumes.
scoring.dangerous: Massive crystalloid resuscitation (>2L) or delayed transport for fluid administration.

critical_decision_points.clinical_anchor: Target SBP 80-90. Normal BP in hemorrhage just means you're pushing clots out faster.
critical_decision_points.aar_teaching_point: Permissive hypotension: In uncontrolled hemorrhage, target SBP 80-90. Higher BP = higher bleeding rate. Crystalloid doesn't clot or carry oxygen. Over-resuscitation causes dilutional coagulopathy, hypothermia, and increased bleeding.

key_concepts: Pelvic fractures can hide 2-4 liters of blood
Pelvic binder is life-saving - reduces pelvic volume for tamponade
Permissive hypotension: target SBP 80-90 until surgical control
Crystalloid doesn't clot or carry oxygen - don't over-resuscitate
Definitive treatment is surgery and blood products
clinical_pearls: Assess pelvis ONCE - each manipulation disrupts clots
External rotation of legs suggests pelvic ring disruption
Blood at perineum = open pelvic fracture = much higher mortality
Scene time correlates with mortality - load and go
Warm fluids if available - hypothermia worsens coagulopathy
